newsitem.title: BELGIUM: EU may review Italian "euro tax" measure for 1997.
newsitem.headline: EU may review Italian "euro tax" measure for 1997.

text.p: Eurostat, the European Union's statistical office, is likely to have to review the Italian government's proposed "euro tax" component of its 1997 budget, a spokesman for the European Commission said on Wednesday.
Replying to questions about the tax, a spokesman said the Commission had previously incorporated the 0.5 percent of GDP tax as a normal tax, not a one-off measure.
The Commission's most recent economic forecasts for the 15-nation bloc put Italy's 1997 deficit at 3.3 percent of total output, just above the Maastricht treaty's 3.0 percent limit.
The Commission spokesman said the EU executive might also have to make an announcement on the legitimacy of the tax as it did in the France Telecom case.

In that case, the French government proposed transferring 37.5 billion francs from France Telecom as a vital element in cutting its 1997 budget deficit to three percent of GDP, the target for EU nations seeking membership of a single currency.

Critics have charged that such one-off measures smacked of creative accounting and ran counter to the Maastricht treaty guidelines for countries seeking to take sustainable economic measures to qualify for the planned 1999 start of the common currency.

The euro tax is a key part of Italy's 1997 budget -- which cleared the lower house of parliament at the weekend -- tailored to lop 62.5 trillion lire off the 1997 public deficit and speed Italy on its way to EMU membership by 1999.
